Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Origins of High Marine Biodiversity in the Indo-Malay-Philippine Archipelago: Transforming a Biodiversity Hotspot into a Research and Education Hotspot.
Award.AbstractNarration:
OISE-0730256 (Carpenter; Old Dominion University Research Foundation)
PIRE: Origins of High Marine Biodiversity in the Indo-Malay-Philippine Archipelago:
Transforming a Biodiversity Hotspot into a Research and Education Hotspot

ABSTRACT

The Indo-Malay-Philippine Archipelago (IMPA) is a biologically, geologically, economically and cultural dynamic region of the world. It is also the global epicenter of marine biodiversity, yet the evolutionary origins of this diversity remain a mystery because the mechanisms driving speciation in the marine realm are poorly understood. Active research in the IMPA pales to the intensive focus on the Great Barrier Reef and Caribbean because of the bureaucratic, cultural and linguistic challenges that face US scientists conducting research in the IMPA. This PIRE (integrated international research and education) project joins the U.S., Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines in researching the distance over which marine populations are connected by larval dispersal, the magnitude of this exchange, the dynamic physical processes that shape dispersal and the evolutionary consequences of the interplay of larvae and their physical environment. Professor Kent Carpenter in the Biological Sciences Department at Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Virginia leads the partnership with two other U.S. institutions: Boston University and Duke University. A number of other U.S. universities will also be participating. The project will train 6 postdocs, 22 graduate students and 16 undergraduate students on the U.S. side over a period of five years. The Indonesian partners are the Indonesia Institute of Sciences, Diponegoro University, the State University of Papua and Udayana University. The Malaysian partners are the University of Sains Malaysia, the Borneo Marine Research Institute and the University of Malaysia. The Philippine partners are the University of the Philippines, the Philippines Bureau of Fisheries and the U.S. Peace Corps in the Philippines. The organization Conservation International is also participating. The resulting international and institutional ties will open new opportunities for exchange among U.S. and IMPA countries.

Moving beyond traditional biogeography and phylogeography, this project is advancing the science of speciation in marine environments by integrating spatially explicit geospatial advective predictive models of larval dispersal with multi-locus estimates of gene flow of fish and invertebrate populations across the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia. A broader impact of this project will be to contribute to marine biodiversity conservation and management. Marine environments provide food, pharmaceuticals and a broad array of ecosystem services, but are in decline worldwide. Understanding the processes that generate marine biodiversity is critical to conservation of marine environments. In particular, knowing how ocean currents affect the dispersal of marine larvae is essential to effective design of marine reserve networks and enhanced management of fisheries at the population level. Better understanding of the origins of marine biodiversity in the IMPA will lead to a better understanding of the evolution of biodiversity on the planet and how to safeguard this biodiversity.

This project is co-funded with the Division of Oceanography in the Directorate for Geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Coral Triangle PIRE (ctPIRE) project was conceived as an innovative integration of evolutionary and population genetics research and collaborative education set in the world’s epicenter of marine biodiversity that includes primarily Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. Using a multi-species approach, the ctPIRE project addresses the Center of Origin hypothesis- that the complex geography and history of sea-level changes has made the Coral Triangle a hotspot of speciation.  Over the lifetime of this project, the tools used to address this hypothesis have evolved from classical genetics approaches such as mitochondrial and microsatellite analyses employing less than 20 unique gene regions to next-generation sequencing platforms and cutting-edge restriction site-associated DNA (RAD) analyses that target tens of thousands of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) across the entire genome. Central to the project’s research is an examination of the patterns of genetic structuring within and across multiple co-distributed species that display a wide variety of biological characteristics and represent a broad spectrum of valued marine resources. Species studied include popular food fishes, targets of the aquarium trade, and vertebrate and invertebrate indicators of rapid alteration of the marine habitat, such as overfishing, reef destruction, and climate change.

 

Another major goal of this project has been to lower barriers to long-term international research in the Indo-Malay-Philippine Archipelago (IMPA) by forging meaningful, lasting collaborations among U.S. and regional scientists and institutions that share common research and education interests. A primary objective has therefore been to build a cohesive research program that enhances our scientific understating of speciation processes in concert with expanding educational capabilities across all institutions, promoting a mutual cultural understanding among US and IMPA scientists.

 

As an essential part of this objective, the ctPIRE project involved a huge network of undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, faculty, government entities, and research institutes. US participants were deployed to the Philippines in 2008 to begin collaborations with the US Peace Corps, De La Salle University (DLSU), the University of the Philippines Marine Science Institute (UPMSI), Silliman University Marine Laboratory (SUML), and the National Fisheries Research and Development Institute (NFRDI). In 2009, ctPIRE operations were expanded to Indonesia and students and scientists from Udayana University and Diponegoro University were brought on as participants. Graduate students from all participating universities, including Old Dominion University (ODU), Boston University, and the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) in the US, were supported by ctPIRE to participate in or conduct research resulting in 11 American theses and dissertations. Undergraduate students from the US were brought into the region for REUs (Research Experience for Undergraduates) as part of the Diversity Project, which was successful in involving under-represented female and minority students in marine sciences and evolutionary biology. Throughout the course of the project, courses and workshops were held to provide students, independent researchers, and faculty with opportunities for enhancing theoretical knowledge and laboratory skills necessary for ctPIRE activities. These included, but were not limited to, multiple molecular ecology summer courses and two bioinformatics and next generation sequencing workshops, held in 2011 and 2014. Further collaborations were fostered in other Indo-Pacific nations, including Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, Papua New Guinea, and Japan.
